column6: The Australia-modified karnofsky Performance scale (AkPs) is a measure of the patient's overall performance status or ability to perform their activities of daily living. it is a single score between 10 and 100 assigned by a clinician based on observations of a patient's ability to perform common tasks relating to activity, work and self-care. A score of 100 signifies normal physical abilities with no evidence of disease. Decreasing numbers indicate a reduced performance status.

PPI uses Palliative Performance Scale along with measures of oral intake, edema, delirium, and dyspnea at rest to predict survival. It has been shown that a PPI of > 6 correlates to a clinical survival of less than 3 weeks.  ~10% patients score <50% would be expected to survive > 6 mo. Certain clinical factors inc predictive value of estimated length of survival when used with performance status. In one small prospective study, for example, it was demonstrated that there was a significant relationship between length of survival and dysphagia, cognitive failure and weight loss. The presence of all three factors – weight loss of 10 kg or more, MMSE of < 24, and dysphagia to solids or liquids predicted survival of less than 4 weeks with an accuracy of 74 %. The estimates in this study were equivalent to that of two physician estimates.	PPI score > 6 = survival shorter than 3 weeks; PPI score >4 = survival shorter than 6 weeks; PPI score ?4 = survival more than 6 weeks

Read horizontally at each level to find a 'best fit' for the patient, who is then assigned as the PPS% score. Begin at the left column and read downwards until the appropriate ambulation level is reached, then read across to the next column and downwards again until the activity/evidence of disease is located. Repeat until all five columns are covered before assigning the actual PPS for that patient. In this way, 'leftward' columns (columns to the left of any specific column) are 'stronger' determinants and generally take precedence over others. 		 	 	 
	
PPS scores are in 10% increments only. Sometimes, there are several columns easily placed at one level but one or two which seem better at a higher or lower level. One then needs to make a 'best fit' decision. Choosing a 'half-fit' value of PPS 45%, for example, is not correct. The combination of clinical judgment and 'leftward precedence' is used to determine whether 40% or 50% is the more accurate score for that patient. PPS may be used for several purposes. First, it is an excellent communication tool for quickly describing a patient's current functional level. Second, it may have value in criteria for workload assessment or other measurements and comparisons. Finally, it appears to have prognostic value.

column3: Debility and Adult Failure to Thrive

column5:
1. ALS tends to progress in a linear fashion over time. Thus the overall rate of decline in each patient is fairly constant and predictable, unlike many other non-cancer diseases.
   2. However, no single variable deteriorates at a uniform rate in all patients. Therefore, multiple clinical parameters are required to judge the progression of ALS.
   3. Although ALS usually presents in a localized anatomical area, the location of initial presentation does not correlate with survival time. By the time patients become end-stage, muscle denervation has become widespread, affecting all areas of the body, and initial predominance patterns do not persist.
   4. Progression of disease differs markedly from patient to patient. Some patients decline rapidly and die quickly; others progress more slowly. For this reason, the history of the rate of progression in individual patients is important to obtain to predict prognosis.
   5. In end-stage ALS, two factors are critical in determining prognosis: ability to breathe, and to a lesser extent ability to swallow. The former can be managed by artificial ventilation, and the latter by gastrostomy or other artificial feeding, unless the patient has recurrent aspiration pneumonia. While not necessarily a contraindication to hospice care, the decision to institute either artificial ventilation or artificial feeding will significantly alter six month prognosis.
   6. Examination by a neurologist within three months of assessment for hospice is advised, both to confirm the diagnosis and to assist with prognosis.

column3: How Do I Care For the Frail?
Goals of Care in the ED
column6: Almost every cognizant person has a sense of self, what (s)he tries to do, how (s)he determines and relates to events, and what (s)he hopes for. People usually developed a sense what brings meaning, value, and adds most to quality of life.  Choices depend on experiences, goals, expectations of future.  goals change over the course of a life. At 1 time or another, many people will confront significant illness and consider the possibility death. Choices for care are based on diagnosis and prognosis, potential benefits/risks of various therapies, personal priorities. Things a person would like to do both in the outside world and personally guides how (s)he would possibly like physicians to address illness. Clarification of goals of care directs recommendations (for medical treatment, surgical interventions, intensity of care). Stimulating this discussion in the ED, even without resolution, can positively impact patient care. Without a roadmap first, you can waste time heading down a wrong direction. Possible goals include prevention, cure, prolongation of life, achieving a good death. No one is inherently most valid, and multiple goals may be simultaneous, but they do inherently interrelate and change. In general, reversing illness and restoring health doesn't preclude goals of relieving suffering and improving quality of life. The 7-step process can be used at any time during a person's illness trajectory. You need certain clinical skills to negotiate goals. Skills for the EP include identifying what is reasonable hope? conveying prognosis (with its uncertainty) using appropriate language, setting limits as needed, managing care if patient lacks decision-making capacity (within norms of patient's culture.) Recognize that ED visits often indicate deterioration of long-standing illness or identification of new dz. new events and changes can cause pt to alter prev goals of care.

column3: Possible Goals For the Emergency physician
column5:
1. Communicate prognosis and its uncertainty
   2. Use language that effectively communicates, negotiates? 
   3. Set limits on unreasonable goals? (e.g. a patient has incurable disease as well as unrealistic hopes for cure)
   4. Adjust care and communication according to patient's culture? 
   5. Meet expectations for treatment and respect and follow personal instructions and decisions to avoid pt['s family] getting angry, losing trust in medical team. 
   6. Avoid unwanted treatments (''What is purpose of performing tests or procedures on this pt?"; ''How will information influence treatment?'')
   7. Avoid inappropriate use of resources (''labs, rad, invasive tests will reveal multiple abnormalities warranting acute hospitalization, but when presented with this info, pt['s fam] respond, ''We just want to go home.''; ask: "What are we hoping to find, and what will I do w/ info?'')
   8. Prevent undue suffering (''Can info or procedure change outcome?'')
   9. Dissipate miscommunication among patient, caregiver, and clinician. 
   10. Understand that curative and palliative goals can coexist--allowing for some treatments to continue rather than change goals and that multiple goals are more common than a single goal. 
   11.  Realize when the dying patient is a child, a parent's realization of prognosis comes late. Multiple goal setting may be particularly common in pediatric or younger patients where the concept of ''giving in'' to death can be particularly overwhelming.
   12. Be culturally aware: 
      1. In general don't apply cultural generalizations to individuals
      2. Ask pt early on preference for your handling of info and who they want to make decisions
      3. Discuss if feasible to get all parties together w/in ED visit, in family meeting so all can hear the patient's disposition
      4. Some cultures prefer medical info, particularly that of a life-threatening px, be given to family not patient. Some Navajos do not want a negative prospect at all
      5. Use 3rd person. e.g. ''If you were hearing a story about someone who was facing an illness that could not be cured, how would you want that story to describe the best way to help?''
column6: Understand that curative and palliative goals can coexist - A patient's overriding goal may be prolonging life, yet (s)he may also have the goal of avoiding increases in discomfort. It is our duty to help the patient and family understand a balance between benefits and burdens of a particular treatment. column3: Who needs a palliative care consult?

column6: Palliative care recognizes 4 paradigm clinical situations.  These should become mental prompts for EP to place pt on appropriate global trajectory. Unlike hospice, palliative care is available at any stage of a life-threatening/serious illness, and is especially helpful to those who wish to continue the pursuit of curative or aggressive care while still receiving optimal symptom control and psychosocial support. Palliative care services focus on goals of care, coordination of care, and aggressive symptom management. Palliative medicine practitioners generally have more time to spend at bedside than ED providers and have expertise with drug dosing/combinations for symptom management which may be unfamiliar to ED or other consults. Early use of palliative care services has demonstrated (1) reduction in length of stay; (2) change of bed assignment based on acuity in order to improve quality care; (3) improved symptom control scores; and (4) increased patient satisfaction. Some ED presentations that might benefit from a palliative care team consult in the ED include: acute stroke in patient with advanced Parkinson's disease; urosepsis in a nursing home resident with advanced dementia; severe pain in patient receiving chemo for metastatic cancer;  pneumonia in a child who has an incurable inborn error of metabolism; unresponsive patient with ROSC after CPR

column3: What does the palliative care team do?
column6: Similar to hospice, the interdisciplinary palliative care consult team may consist of a physician, RN, social worker, a chaplain, and administrator; or it may include only an RN and physician. The American Board of Medical Subspecialties recognized palliative care in 2006. By 2007 there were >2,000 diplomate members, with board certification available to 10 subspecialties (Anesthesiology, EM, FM, IM, Pediatrics, PM and R, Psychiatry and Neurology, Radiology, Surgery, OB/Gyn. Not all physicians who practice palliative care are board certified, but are supported by their institutions as palliative care practitioners, and may be vying for board certification. Some palliative care programs allow advanced practice RNs with palliative care training to assist in consults. Other programs have a master's level, board-certified palliative care nurse practitioner may practice in parallel with physicians and who can diagnose/manage common physical, spiritual, psychological, and social needs of patients in need of palliative care.  Effective palliative care teams use all members of the interdisciplinary team to respond to consults. assessments and recommendations of social workers, chaplains, administrators who work within palliative care can be far more important contributors to wellness than RNs/physicians: an intervention by these team members in the ED can be a crucial point for patients and families struggling with end-of-life issues. Some services combine pain and palliative care services; others have an independent pain service addressing both pain management and other distressing symptoms. Palliative care services are justified by added service and/or cost avoidance, even though they don't generate significant fee-for-service revenue. they are sometimes supported by partnerships w/ community- or hospital-based hospices.

25% of U.S. hospitals have a palliative care service, some of which are available for ED consults, yet not used by EPs. Preliminary data show we can identify a large number of patients with palliative care needs on arrival to the ED. Some of these are available for consultations in the ED, yet many ED personnel do not use these services. Preliminary data indicate that a large number of patients with palliative care needs can be identified on arrival in the ED. calling a palliative care consult in the ED reduces ICU time (significantly reducing cost), but also improves quality of care, allows for the provision of excellent symptom management. patient's who had palliative care consults had reduced length of hospital stay, changed bed assignments which improved quality of care, improved symptom control score, increased patient satisfaction scores!

      Even after adv care planning, research suggests EP\'s may not follow a legal directive. Of the 1,252 EP respondents 78% said they would honor legal advance directives regarding resuscitation, 7% said they would comply with unofficial documents, 6% said they would comply with verbal reports of advance directives, 62% reported that their decisions about resuscitation were based on fear of litigation or criticism, 55% said they have recently attempted numerous resuscitations despite expectations that such efforts would be futile, 78% indicated that, ideally, legal concerns should not influence a physician's decision about the practice of resuscitation, but most (94%) also felt that, in the current environment, legal concerns do influence practice. These findings underscore how advance care planning can fail to have its intended effect because emergency physicians do not know how to interpret and institute advance directives.

column3: Illness is a threat to the family system and can amplify existing problems
column6: Few families function perfectly, but they are often the primary social unit that meets many human needs. It almost follows, that families have problems. Illness/changes in health may change individual roles, or may threaten the system and amplify existing problems. E.g., if the patient can no longer relate meaningfully to others, other members may take on new roles. Or if the family's primary provider is a trauma victim in your ED, other members may be too disoriented to make decisions or provide care as they are unfamiliar with this role. Death also impacts system and individual family members.

column3: Know the factors that influence family coping

column6: Family structure and roles Families vary widely in nature and composition. There are families of origin, families of choice, families within families, and communities that function like families. How does the patient's family system function? Ask, ''What roles have [you] played in health care?'' ''How has everyone been changed by the illness?''  ''Are your roles strained?'' Is the family system in equilibrium or in danger of losing function? Illness demands a lot, and patients with limited social support systems will likely have unmet needs. Some vacant roles may be care providers, advocates, trusted companions, and surrogate decision makers. Find out if the surrogate decision maker knows his or her role?  Does (s)he know the patient's wishes for medical care in both the present and possible future scenarios? Caring for someone with a serious, terminal illness is very hard work, physically, emotionally, spiritually, and practically; and family/caregivers are themselves at risk for illness. Think of all as valued members of the care team, but also as second-order patients.

column3: Stage in the Patient\'s Life Cycle
column6: Stage in the patient's life cycle Illness impacts people drastically, and the person's life-cycle stage affects this impact. Most people do not expect to encounter terminal illness before aging. most people feel that terminal illness is more appropriate to the latter stages of the life cycle. Life-cycle stage also affects physiological resilience and responses to illness and treatments. consider how the illness interacts with typical stressors of a given life-cycle stage.  how will illness/treatment demands impact the family at its current developmental stage. other strains and stressors associated with life-cycle stages include a new baby, job change, or recent loss. spirituality/faith the presence or absence of spiritual beliefs or a faith community affect how individuals/families cope. Beliefs and faith communities can bring spiritual, psychological, social, and practical support, or a source of distress at an already difficult time. know the patient's beliefs to help and assess whether suffering may be aided/undermined by the patient's spiritual life. Illness impacts spiritual well-being/trust in a beneficent being for a patient/family. some find faith becomes the all important comfort. humans tend to create a meaning/understanding of events, making it natural that illness impacts spiritual life. this can help us identify spiritual crises to refer to a counselor/chaplain to restore comfort in faith/access the faith community.
Cultural values and beliefs contribute to understanding, preferences, coping patterns, and greatly determine the family's experience.

Cohesion among family members varies and can be disengaged or separated, connected, or enmeshed. Cohesion (or lack thereof) affects family supports a patient, and how you communicate with family. communication within a family is driven partly by the individuals and partly by the cultural context. Normal levels of sharing and support can vary widely between (and within) cultures. if you know the norms you can suggest how to handle medical information and decision-making (sharing bad news, care planning) and honor boundaries of confidentiality/inclusiveness of family members

column3: Issues/uses of Hospice in the ED
column6: EP's can formulate next best steps of a care if we know the barriers to hospice, especially those in some nursing homes. We should know how to initiate a referral, and understand services hospice does and does not offer; not insignificantly, because it can become more difficult for patients and caregivers to accept or continue hospice if we give inaccurate information about the system, symptom management, or related decision making. Most patients will receive care at home while they are receiving hospice services and will never access the ED, but many ED presentations each year are either receiving or would benefit from hospice-type services. Initiating these services and seamlessly transitioning to hospice from the ED can provide relief of suffering and facilitate a higher quality of life. A challenge is that providers view hospice as appropriate only when a patient is obviously dying or very near death, resulting in one-third of the more than 1 million Americans referred for hospice dying in <7 days and over half dying in the first 30 days. There is an initiative for earlier referrals to hospice care to allow more to benefit from services for weeks and months, not days. The terminal phase of illness is difficult to predict, but lack of understanding about formulating an estimate partially explains why many Americans receive services only at the extreme end of life

column6: In previous centuries, the primary goal of medicine was to provide comfort, but in the latter half of the 20th century there have been significant developments in science and technology waging an aggressive  fight against illness and death.  The primary goals shifted to curing illness and prolonging life. In this  process, we have at times paid less attention to symptoms, the relief of suffering, and care of the dying. In the 1960s and 1970s, hospice and palliative care movements sprang up in the United Kingdom, United States, and Canada to fill a void caring for the dying. Historically, the US Medicare hospice benefit covered hospice care of last 6 mo of life.  Programs tended to admit patients with incurable cancer. More recently, hospice and palliative care programs have been evolving into medical practices and programs that focus on relief of suffering and improvement in quality of life for those patients who have a broader range of prognoses.  a newer paradigm of palliative medicine, addresses the problem of the historical dichotomy of medical decision making for goals of care first focused on therapies with curative intent and only later shifting goals/decisions to relieve suffering only when those therapies are no longer effective. This common current situation has been defined partly by the Medicare hospice benefit, which requires that a patient's prognosis must be <6 months and that patient must agree to forego any therapy with a curative intent in order to avail themselves of this benefit. However, many patients, families, and professionals are not prepared to give up therapies aimed at cure and life-prolongation in order to focus totally on relief of suffering. Thus, an unintended consequence of the original legislation has been that many dying Americans are never referred to hospice programs. Moreover, studies show that patients with life-threatening illness experience multiple symptoms and ongoing needs for psychological, social, spiritual, and practical support. Relief of suffering should be pursued where suffering exists. Clinicians should not wait for the point at which all attempts for cure are exhausted, or the patient/caregivers plead to suddenly stop curative efforts and focus on the relief of suffering. With earlier access to palliative care,, patients and families may feel better, be able to continue in a more normal lifestyle, maintain more capacity to fight the illness and undergo treatment, and have a better capacity to accomplish personal goals in the later stages of life.  ''hospice'', from the Latin hospitium, meaning guesthouse. During the 1960s, Dr. Cicely Saunders established the modern hospice movement at St. Christopher\'s Hospice near London which initiated an organized team approach to professional palliative caregiving. The U.S. first hospice was in New Haven, Connecticut in 1974. In the U.S., hospice evolved primarily as a home care program. It currently cares for about 1/3 of all dying Americans, and is the most comprehensive system for the terminally ill in the U.S. Medicare pays for 85% of all hospice care in the United States. Insurers other than Medicare also cover hospice services. They base eligibility on (and provide services that mimic) the Medicare hospice benefit. Most hospice companies in the United States follow the federal guidelines set forth in the Medicare hospice benefit so that they can submit charges to Medicare. It's focus is comfort and the acceptance of death as natural. Although hospice provides service to anyone with terminal illness, ? of dying americans don't use it.. Some never accept they have limited life expectancy, some may see hospice as ''giving up'', and some providers feel uncomfortable with services or referrals. Only a fraction of eligible patients who die in the U.S. actually receive hospice care. In 2004, median length of stay for a Medicare beneficiary receiving hospice was 15 days. 75% of hospice patients died outside a hospice facility in a private residence, nursing home, or other residential facility. largest group of hospice patients had cancer (46%), but 54% with other diseases are increasingly cared for under hospice. in 2004: heart disease (12%), dementia (9.8%), debility (9.2%), and lung disease (7.3%). Over 90% of hospice patients were over the age of 65.

column3: MYTH 10: If the physician certifies prognosis of <6 months, and the patient lives longer, the physician gets in trouble with the insurer and/or government.
column6: There is no penalty to any physician who has acted in good faith if the patient does not die in 6 months. The physician is certifying that it is his or her clinical opinion that, if the disease runs its usual course, the physician would not be surprised if the patient died within the 6-month time frame. For a condition with a prognosis of six months, in a population with that condition, half will live less and half will live more. In fact, patients often live longer in hospice, some for years. A physician certifies at each reassessment. If the patient lives longer than expected, they aren't necessarily removed from hospice; but, there are cases where reassessments indicate the disease isn't following its usual course, so this patient may be discharged from hospice. (S)he may re-enroll if condition deteriorates and recertification of <6month  prognosis is probable again.

column6: e.g Feeding tube or airway. Hospice practitioners may lack experience necessary to replace devices. Most common ED presentations for palliative care patients are lost gastrostomy tubes and tracheal airways which can cause panic in patients and families. The lay or professional home care provider not uncommonly dislodges device in moving the patient. Before replacing the device in the ED, determine if patient/surrogate thinks it's still necessary: don't assume the wish is to continue the device just because they came to the ED. They may want an opportunity to discuss its effectiveness. you can/should give permission to discontinue its use if it isnt meeting the patient\'s goals. the percutaneous gastrostomy tube (PEG) is the most available and most commonly used enteral feeding devices in palliative care patients. head and neck cancer patients may have pharyngostomy or esophagostomy tubes, or gastroenterostomy, duodenostomy,  jejunostomy tubes for complicated resections. You cannot tell what kind of enteral tube it is solely by physical examination. column3: Examples for addressing general fiscal concerns
column5:
Example 1. Mrs. Jones is receiving hospice services for terminal breast cancer with metastasis to her femur. She is washing dishes and cuts her hand on a knife. Is this service covered by the hospice? No. The hospice provider is responsible only for those services related to the primary certifying diagnosis. In this case, her laceration is unrelated to her cancer and thus Medicare Part A and B or her regular insurer would pay for charges related to the laceration.

Example 2. Mrs. Jones is receiving hospice services for terminal breast cancer with metastasis to her femur. She falls, sustains a femur fracture, and presents to the ED. Is this service covered by the hospice? Yes. The fracture is clearly related to the cancer. The hospice is responsible for using the per diem rate to pay for services for Mrs. Jones' care. In the case of this ED visit, the hospice would pay the hospital for services rendered to Mrs. Jones in the ED and the hospice would get no additional money from the regular insurer.

Example 3. Mrs. Jones is receiving hospice services for terminal breast cancer with metastasis to her femur and she also has diabetes. She presents to the ED with uncontrolled diabetes. You would like to discharge her on diabetic medications. Does hospice cover the cost of her diabetes medications? No. The only medicines covered by hospice are the ones related to the primary certifying diagnosis. In this case, terminal breast cancer is not the primary cause of the diabetes, the diabetes is deemed to be unrelated, and the medicines are not covered by the hospice.

Example 4. Mrs. Jones is receiving hospice services for terminal breast cancer with metastasis to her femur and she also has diabetes. She presents to the ED with uncontrolled pain. Does the hospice cover the ED visit? Possibly. The hospice must approve any ED visits. Pain control is routinely provided by the hospice. The hospice will often review a case such as this and determine whether the patient or the hospice will have to pay for the ED visit.

column3: Barriers to end-of-life care in some nursing homes

column5: EPs care for many nursing home patients at end of life, so: ''Why can't they take care of this at the nursing home?''
column6: Although nearly ? of all older adults die in the nursing home, the majority die without comprehensive palliative care (or hospice) benefits. The Institute of Medicine has reported/identified many problems in long-term care. The challenges of this setting are monumental: staffing shortages, admission of increasingly sicker patients to staff lacking the training to care for such patients. Nursing home staff can become close patients-and panic just as families do. a nursing home transfers patients in last days or months of illness for many reasons which may not include reversing or treating the underlying illness.  they are usually unexpected circulatory, respiratory, CNS compromise; fracture; injury; infection, and are influenced by severity of the underlying problem, availability of nursing home services, and family request for transfer.

column3: Low rates of hospice use by nursing home patients
column6: Hospice use in U.S. nursing homes went from 11% in 1992 to 35% in 2000. despite an estimated 75% of U.S. nursing homes having some form of partnership with a hospice with contracts to meet regulatory guidelines for each party, the nursing home may not regularly use hospice services. The responsibility to oversee hospice services is left to the patient's attending physician, therefore nursing homes may not have procedures to ensure patients receive the services. There are many hurdles to good end-of-life care in the long-term care setting. Quality indicators for the terminally ill suggest at a minimum, nursing homes provide pain and dyspnea management, and advance care planning. A project funded by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, Best Practices for Nursing Home End-of-Life Care (Executive Summary 2007), looked for collaborative solutions and found that patients at EOL enrolled in hospice have a higher quality of care, lower rates of hospitalization; and that nursing homes w/ a hospice presence positively affect non-hospice residents. The report concluded that successful collaborations of long term facilities enact consistency and communication and a customer service approach. features of these partnerships included a norm of mutual respect; routine knowledge sharing between providers; policies and procedures that clarified each collaborating party's role, and a hospice presence.

The Centers for Medicaid Services recommends a minimum of 2 hours/day of aid by a certified nurses' aid, 45 minutes by a licensed practical nurse, 12 minutes by an RN. In 2004, a review of data over 8-years revealed 90% of nursing homes weren't providing this minimum standard.

Ironically, nursing home education does not routinely include palliative and hospice care for their nurses, who interact with patients most and who may be most capable to recognize someone's end-of-life needs. Good end of life care depends on the nursing staff negotiating and supporting goals of care

Under federal guidelines, an attending physician must visit the nursing home patient, but the time period varies. PCPs should visit each resident at least once every 30 days for the first 90 days after admission, and at least once every 60 days afterwards, but they may delegate every other scheduled visit to an NP or PA if within their scope of practice and state regulations. The typical physician who cares for a nursing home patient spends < 2 hours per week in the nursing home. Medicare requires newly admitted patients be asked about wishes for advance directives; not that the physician, patient, or surrogates discuss resuscitation status, which typically does not occur.

If we begin discussing the option of hospice referral in the ED, we may improve end-of-life care in the nursing home. EDs can develop mechanisms with long-term care agencies to improve hospice and palliative care options for patients.

column3: How Do I Manage Common Symptoms?

column6: Pain management is appropriately emphasized in advanced illnesses; however, most suffer from non-pain symptoms which can be even more distressing to patients and families. Unrelieved symptoms may preclude goals of relieving psychological, social, spiritual suffering, improving quality of life, and achieving closure. it goes against our Emergency Medicine training at times and makes us sometimes uneasy to focus on symptoms, which we see as clues to diagnosis which will improve as we address the disease. But when we act without full understanding of the pathophysiology, pharmacology, interventions AND the potential risks, interactions, or adverse effects of appropriate medications, we undertreat symptoms. E.g. wide prevalence of hypoalgesia in malignant pain patients presenting to the ED. Moreover, symptom relief may be all that is required when the goals of care preclude disease management. You might not need to wait for more work up, if symptoms are debilitating or patient is too weak to undergo interventions/investigations. use continuous or around-the-clock medication administration for continuous  symptoms with breakthrough doses PRN (e.g. malignant pain). Key is in educating/involving patient and family caregivers. you may encourage a diary after they leave the ED to facilitate future OP or IP management. if management is complex (e.g.  if symptoms are interrelated and multiple occur together), consult palliative care and members of the interdisciplinary team to optimize therapy and minimize adverse drug events and interactions

Sense of drowning or being smothered, can be one of the most frightening symptoms for patients/caregivers. Relief in end of life care can be straightforward for many patients if we understand breathlessness, the meds used to manage it.  without this understanding, our fear of adverse effects can lead to inadequate relief and unnecessary suffering/use of mechanical ventilation.

Frequently we can't and shouldn't identify or correct the underlying etiology of air hunger-- if the burden of investigations and disease-modifying interventions outweigh potential of benefit in advanced disease Therapeutic trials based on known history frequently focus on symptom relief.

Research has shown opioids can relieve breathlessness in patients without deranged respiratory rate or ABGs, but the precise mechanism is unclear, but thought to include central and peripheral effects. Sub-analgesic doses may work in the opioid-nai?ve. To simplify dosing, establish the effective dose, and convert it to an extended-release preparation. Using opiates should equate to preparing to concomitantly manage their adverse effects (e.g. the ubiquitous, inevitable constipation). nebulized opioids anecdotally reported to be effective, but in phase II studies and placebo-controlled studies, they weren't superior to nebulized saline.
Pharmacologic tolerance and any fear of addiction is clinically insignificant in managing breathlessness in advanced illness. Relieving the symptom of dyspnea may actually increase exercise tolerance and mobility. It has been shown that when dosing guidelines for dyspnea are followed, respiratory depression doesn't occur.The principle of double effect is commonly cited in cases where physician treats with intent/expectation of a good outcome (eg, relieve a symptom), while knowing there's a chance for an undesired, secondary effect (e.g. death). Many feel this action is ethical after informed consent is obtained.  all treatments have both intended effects and unintended, potentially adverse, consequences. Many believe opioids/anxiolytics have unusually or unacceptably high risk of adverse event that could end a life, particularly in the frail near that end of life if used improperly or, in rare cases, when used properly. we should understand then discuss all potential benefits/risks with patients with cognizance of goals for care. In symptom control, however, this principle rarely applies. The secondary adverse consequence of death is not likely to occur. Clouding this ethical construct/intuition is the notion that suffering states might make death an appealing choice. We know treatments carry a risk of adverse events, e.g. death, for many interventions and noninterventions; e.g. chemotherapy, surgery, TPN for short gut syndrome, or stopping all tests or avoiding surgery respectively. currently, most deem an action ethical if: (a) the intent is to relieve suffering and not hasten death, (b) death is a possible but not inevitable outcome of the interventions, and (c) there is fully informed consent. if action is intended to cause death as a means end suffering/control symptoms, less agree on its morality. physician-assisted suicide and euthanasia are quite different both clinically and ethically. But, an opioid can be safely used for breathlessness with very minimal risk of death, if accepted dosing guidelines are followed. So many providers grossly over estimate and don't understood the risk of respiratory depression. Drowsiness, confusion, depressed consciousness occur long before respiratory rate is compromised particularly in someone in acute pain, hence the effectiveness of PCA's and regimens based on sound pharmacology.

These are common in many advanced diseases. Nausea is an unpleasant subjective sensation secondary to stimulation of GI lining, the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the base of the fourth ventricle, the vestibular apparatus, or the cerebral cortex. the vomiting center directs the neuromuscular reflex of a final common pathway, i.e.  vomiting, after stimulation of one or more of these areas. Stimulation is by the neurotransmitters serotonin, dopamine, acetylcholine, and histamine which are all within the chemoreceptor trigger zone. they are all also present (with serotonin playing a large role) in the lining of the GI tract. Acetylcholine and histamine are predominant players in vestibular apparatus. The  awareness of nausea, inability to keep food or fluids down, the associated acid and bitter tastes, and unpleasant smells of vomitus may be distressing. cortex stimulation and responses are complex, not associated with specific neurotransmitters, and seem to be learned (eg, the anticipatory nausea associated with chemotherapy or nausea related to anxiety).

Multiple causes for nausea and vomiting, but symptom relief is usually achieved if we choose the right meds and understand them.  choosing the right drug depends on targeting the etiologies, but it's frequently not possible to identify or specifically correct the underlying etiology. Therapeutic trials may suggest the etiology. When causes are known, the burden of the disease-modifying intervention may outweigh the potential benefit. Empiric antiemetics usually starts with one med that targets the presumed mechanism. optimize that dose dose before adding a second med/different mechanism of action. Sequential combination therapy may be required in some patients.

column5:
1. Chronic Pain--traditionally defined as pain >6mo.
      1. Sustained by a complex neurological process. Pathology may be unknown. may be recurrent: chronic, persists with pain-free intervals. may be due to demonstrable pathophysiological causes or there may be no demonstrable pathology that causes the pain. Chronic pain syndromes are thought to be sustained by a more complex process governed by AMPA, (alpha-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methylsexazole-4-proprionic acid), the glutamate-mediated NMDA receptor, nitrous oxide (NO), and substance P. Central sensitization is the normal response to a persistent noxious stimuli. Chronic stimulation of the NMDA receptor results in substance P release which stimulates nerve regrowth in the spinal cord and remodeling to produce changes consistent with those found in neuropathic pain, including sensory alterations such as allodynia and hyperalgesia. Central sensitization and activation of the NMDA receptors is thought to decrease responsiveness to endorphins and exogenous opioids. It is thought that the new neuronal connections that are formed in chronic pain lack mu-receptors and this has an important implication in opioid responsiveness. Notably however, drugs that antagonize the NMDA receptor (eg, ketamine and methadone) may be more helpful.
   2. Acute Pain-the normal, predicted physiological response to a noxious chemical, thermal or mechanical stimulus, generally time-limited and typically associated with invasive procedures, trauma and disease.
      1. traditionally defined as <30 days, subacute 1-6 months. In acute pain nocioceptors are stimulated and transmit nerve impulses to the spinal cord then higher centers. it's associated with an autonomic response. Epinephrine and norepinephrine acutely induce tachycardia, small vessel vasoconstriction, diaphoresis, and a sense of dread. It is thought to be adaptive for the individual to stop or avoid the offending agent. Current models suggest additional maladaptive features, e.g. altered immune response.
   3. Malignant Pain--
   4. Oligoanalgesia--
   5. Chemical Coping--
   6. Addiction-the persistent compulsive use of drugs
      1. which is a primary, chronic, neurobiologic process influenced by genetic, psychosocial, and environmental factors. Characteristic behaviors include: impaired control over drug use, craving, compulsive and continued use despite harm. Physical dependence and tolerance are normal physiological consequences of extended opioid therapy for pain and are not the same as addiction.
   7. Chronic Pain-a state in which pain persists beyond a usual course of acute disease or healing of an injury.
      1. It may or may not be associated with an acute or chronic pathologic process causing continuous or intermittent pain over months or years. Chronic pain is not acute pain, and it is not necessarily nonmalignant. if chronic pain is not malignant, if not malignant, chronic pain is experienced within context of disease experience in serious or life-threatening illness. like in all palliative care, attend to physical, psychological, social, spiritual issues w/ (non)pharmacological approach
   8. Pain-An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage or described in terms of such damage.
   9. Physical Dependence-a state of adaptation manifested by drug class-specific signs/symptoms which can be reproduced by abrupt cessation, rapid dose reduction, decreasing serum levels of the drug, and/or administration of an antagonist.
      1. Physical dependence, by itself, is not pathognomonic/diagnostic of addiction. non-opioid meds exhibiting physical dependence include corticosteroids, beta-blockers, and alpha-adrenergic agents.
   10. Pseudoaddiction-An iatrogenic syndrome, in which providers misinterpret relief-seeking behaviors for drug-seeking (commonly seen with addiction). 
   11. Substance Abuse-use of any substance(s) for non-therapeutic or purposes other than those for which it is prescribed (e.g. recreational or psychological).
   12. Tolerance-a physiologic state in which regular use of a drug results in the need to increase the dose to achieve a specific effect, or using a constant dose over time reduces an effect.
      1. Tolerance may or may not be evident during opioid treatment and does not equate with addiction.

column6: The NMDA receptor may be involved in the spinal neural circuitry involved in neuropathic pain, a physiologic state resistant to high dose opioids. dextromethorphan and ketamine have shown some mild pain effects in clinical studies, along with significant dose-related side effects. Methadone is a racemic mix of levo and dextro isomers: the levo form binds at opioid receptors and both forms can block the NMDA receptor. But, the equianalgesic dose of methadone varies greatly, and depends on how much oral morphine equivalent a patient takes. It is hypothesized that by being both an opioid receptor agonist and an NMDA-receptor antagonist, methadone is much more potent than expected. So some find methadone to be an effective second-line opioid for neuropathic pain; but some find it too fickle.

The nonselective sodium channel inhibitors have been used for neuropathic pain. Parenteral lidocaine has shown efficacy in diabetic neuropathy, trigeminal neuralgia, and other neuropathic pain syndromes. Typically effective serum levels range from 2-5 mg/L. But, there is little data in the end-of-life population. Oral anesthetics/antiarrhythmics such as mexiletine have been used successfully in neuropathic pain. Monitor for cardiac toxicity. Topical lidocaine patches are approved for post-herpetic neuralgia. In the future, it may be possible to block a specific subset of sodium channels involved mediating pain transmission.

column6: There are a myriad of medications prescribed for chronic pain, but we are most often faced with the challenge of whether to refill or initiate opioids. Opioids may or may not be helpful in the case of chronic pain because of the complexity of the disease. In the case of opioid-responsive chronic pain, it is medically and ethically appropriate to treat with an opioid. There is literature that suggests that the use of opioids in chronic pain may be more harmful than helpful when used inappropriately and that chronic opioids in nonmalignant pain should be properly assessed for effectiveness, closely monitored, and titrated by a single provider or practice. There is great consensus that the therapy should be closely monitored for effectiveness with an interdisciplinary approach to physical, psychological, and social factors. It is imperative that the clinician understand that a patient with chronic pain or an acute exacerbation is unlikely to benefit from treatment unless there is a comprehensive pain care model and that what appear to be sympathetic efforts in the ED to manage chronic pain may not be the right plan. The American Academy of Pain Medicine and the American Pain Society believe that the principles of good medical practice should guide safe opioid prescribing in chronic pain. Based on the history, physical, and comprehensive ED pain assessment, it may be entirely appropriate to initiate or refill opioids for an ED patient with chronic nonmalignant pain. When initiating or refilling opioids, however, it is important to ensure that a global care plan is in place. Patients or their surrogate(s) should be informed of the risks, benefits, and conditions of opioid prescribing, and told that periodic review is necessary to assess global functioning. They should also be made aware that opioids may not be helpful as a pain management strategy. Far too often, patients leave the ED with an opioid prescription but with poor documentation and this can potentially keep difficult pain cases from being followed and referred appropriately.

Screening for addiction and abuse is difficult in a busy environment where access to medical history may be limited or unavailable. Screening for aberrant behaviors may be useful because aberrant behaviors can be indicative of addiction and misuse, but such behaviors are not diagnostic. A pattern of aberrancy may be more helpful in determining if abuse or addiction exists. The psychoneurophysiologic basis and somatic molecular mediators for stress of etiologies (including loss, grief, and bereavement) are becoming better understood. People who take care of the patient also suffer losses as their lives change and they share the experience with the patient. In addition to challenges, each loss also presents opportunities for new perspectives on living, heightened spiritual awareness, and chances to resolve conflicts and find greater acceptance of oneself, others, and the world. People often find ways to make these opportunities part of the adaptation to loss. Despite the ubiquitous nature of patients facing losses due to illness and despite the frequency with which physicians encounter bereaved patients and families, medical education has provided minimal training on how to provide care during this aspect of a patient's experience or on how to care for bereaved people.

Grief is a personal and normal response to a loss. It can be emotional, intellectual, spiritual, physical, behavioral, or social. Mourning is the act of grieving. It can involve private expressions and experiences of grief, and socially and culturally defined customs such as rituals and traditions. Mourning is the outward experience of a loss; grief and bereavement are components of the process of accommodating a loss. Immediately after a death, those who are bereaved will need time to recover from their acute stress and fatigue and to restore their environments to a more normal state. As they begin to realize the significance of the loss, they will likely experience an intense grief reaction with multiple cognitive, emotional, and physical responses and will require considerable ongoing support to help them deal with all the changes. Some people who are bereaved will make a conscious effort to deal with the loss, emotions, and changes that follow the death of a loved one and to seek ongoing assistance from their physicians to help them address their feelings of loss. Others will deny what is happening and avoid dealing with any of these issues. The latter group will be at high risk for a prolonged, complicated, grieving process.
Theoretical perspectives have offered frameworks for understanding why we grieve. Bowlby suggested that grief occurs when an attachment necessary to one's safety and security is disrupted. Others consider grief a part of the healing process that is necessary to reestablish equilibrium in a person's life after the loss of a loved one.

column3: Bereavement is the state of living with a loss
column6: Loss can occur at any time (for example, loss of a sense of future, function, body image, relationships, control, independence, dignity). Each loss produces a grief response and the intensity of the response will vary depending on the importance of the loss. Bereavement is associated with declines in health, inappropriate health services use, and increased risk of death. It heightens a person's risk for depression, insomnia, suicide attempts, death, and increased consumption of alcohol, tobacco, and tranquilizers.

column3: Factors affecting time course of adaptation to loss.
column6: Taking in the reality of a loss can take days to weeks. Adjusting to the loss can take weeks to months or even years. Interference with normal life should lessen over weeks to months, depending on the nature of the loss. Most bereaved people are able to reenter the world after one to three weeks, but they can continue to experience active grieving for a year or more. Although sadness can continue for a much longer period of time, it typically does not intrude on or prevent new life. Over a period of a year or two, most people are able to engage in relationships that have emotional meaning in the same sphere as the relationship that they had with the person who died. The time course of adaptation among terminally ill patients who are facing losses is harder to assess, but adaptation does occur. great variation in length of adaptive process. For some losses, grief continues for several months to several years. Grief may continue longer in some situations.

Bonanno and others have found that psychological resilience is more common during bereavement than previously thought. These works suggest that there are multiple trajectories for the grief process, including those that involve intense, negative, emotional experiences throughout the course as well as those that involve psychological growth.
The emotional reactions to a loss are frequently volatile and may crescendo as everyone confronts the possibility that the patient may die and the changes that death will bring. Perceived loss requires adaptation. This is true whether the perceived loss is in the physical, psychological, social, or existential domain. Creative adaptations to loss can sustain a person through repeated and severe losses, but creative adaptation is not easy. For those facing cancer, the demands are often repeated and severe, and adaptation can be difficult. It is an integral part of comprehensive care to assist patients and families in achieving the adaptations that will allow them to maintain a quality existence.
Before any adaptation is likely to be an optimal fit, it is first necessary to understand the nature and the implications of a loss, discard exaggerated fears, and accept unwanted realities
However, the emotional responses to loss can be so great that comprehension is difficult. Some people need discussion and repeated fact checking. Some need a tangible event. Others simply need time to let the realities sink in.
Many people need to disconnect from their previous interests as they internally adapt and then reintegrate, without what has been lost, as a whole person who is once again ready for relationships with others.

One of the first losses that a patient with a life-threatening condition faces is often loss of confidence about the future. Even patients who do not lose hope probably confront this adjustment in some fashion. A serious diagnosis almost inevitably raises a person's awareness of mortality and puts it in a new light. This existential challenge is likely to have ramifications in the psychological and relational domains.

Physical losses and engagement in new approaches to life precipitate a changed self- image. Whether hair loss, weight loss, breast loss, or limb loss has occurred, self-image must be adjusted. It would be ideal if the patient and family could learn to feel good about the new physical form, but it is often difficult to achieve positive feelings after such a loss.

When facing serious or life-threatening illness, patients and family members may modify established roles or even take on new roles, with varying degrees of personality fit for those roles. The patient may take on the sick role and family members may take on the caregiver role. Transitions into these new roles can develop slowly or rapidly, with varying mixes of earlier roles and varying degrees of resistance and expectations of role definitions. In the sick role, the person may take on an identity of being sick. He or she expects, and is expected, to be cared for by others who tend to needs that he or she cannot fulfill alone. In the caregiving role, family members may adopt different caregiving activities and corresponding identities as they settle into expectations for the activities and resulting relationships. Role transitions can be difficult. For instance, as the patient becomes unable to perform instrumental and core activities of daily living, the caregiver must learn how to help with personal function. This type of intimacy may not be welcome because it involves different self-images and relational boundaries. A sense of loss of the patient's former self may exist for both the patient and the caregiver. It may be necessary for each party to experiment with various ways of performing the roles. The physician can help by acknowledging and normalizing the attention that these transitions require and by emphasizing that they do not always go smoothly and may demand the types of relational coping skills that family members have found helpful in other stressful adaptations. With adjustment, the caregiving role can yield gratification. It can also be accompanied by significant burdens. Caregivers experience worse health outcomes than their matched counterparts.

Society assigns a slightly different role to people who are expected to die soon. They are no longer expected to struggle for cure and recovery. They are expected to achieve peace with others and to offer parting gestures. Dying people are expected to reach some type of conclusion on their life story or personal legacy. They are expected to make practical arrangements for material gifts and sometimes for their own death-related events, such as a funeral. They may be expected to designate successors to the roles they have held during their lives, such as asking a child to ''look after mother for me'' or asking a friend to ''see to the finances for my child.''

column6:
Although important, new roles can be detrimental if entered into prematurely. The patient can feel discarded before his or her time, and the future caregiver or future successor can feel that he or she has made serious errors in a role that he or she cared deeply about. Patients and families can be encouraged to settle their differences where possible and to enjoy the peace that results. Suggestions can be offered about making practical arrangements early, with the explicit acknowledgement that it is intended to get things squared away rather than to usher in an expected death. The notion of ''planning for the eventuality while living for quality relationships'' can be helpful. Preparations for the future may be especially helpful for close caregivers because they may have difficulty transitioning out of such an all-consuming role. In addition to the changing social roles, personal relationships are also often in transition. Personal needs change. The capacity to relate in previously habitual ways changes. The patient can feel abandoned if his or her significant other turns out to be ill-suited to the caregiver role. Family members can feel abandoned if the patient can no longer perform in the ways he or she used to. Sexual drive and capacity may change, with ensuing changes in associated meaning and emotional needs. Favorite recipes may taste different, detracting from the gratifications of cooking and eating together. The bathroom, bedroom, and living areas may be transformed by medical equipment that reminds people of sickness or death. The physician has a great deal of power to normalize the feelings associated with these changes and should remain alert to the possible need for counseling. Patient losses result in family losses. As the patient loses functions, the family tends to take up the slack. This may entail gains in roles or relationships, but there are usually losses as well. Family members may have to quit their jobs, let go of the expectations they had of a mother or spouse or child, make time to perform domestic functions, and so on. Adaptations by family members are an integral part of the process of living with a life-limiting or life-threatening illness, adjusting to losses, and to eventual bereavement. Comprehensive patient care requires an awareness of these needs and intervention that will help meet the needs. The patient is not likely to do as well if his or her family is failing to cope.

Caregiver - The cumulative effect of loss can be overwhelming for the physician and the health care team. To enhance their own effectiveness, those in the helping professions need to be keenly aware of their own vulnerability and take the necessary steps to protect themselves. Feelings of powerlessness, inadequacy, and isolation can be mitigated by utilizing self-care approaches that incorporate the mental, physical, emotional, and spiritual dimensions. By balancing work life with other activities, the ED team will be able to respond more appropriately to the emotional needs of patients and their families.

column6: Uncomplicated grief reactions include a wide range of physical, emotional, spiritual, and cognitive behaviors. The bereaved person may note feelings of hollowness in the stomach, tightness in the chest, heart palpitations, weakness, lack of energy, gastrointestinal disturbances, weight gain or loss, or skin reactions. Many say they feel emotional numbness, relief, sadness, fear, anger, guilt, loneliness, abandonment, despair, or ambivalence. The bereaved person may be concerned about cognitive symptoms such as disbelief, confusion, inability to concentrate, and preoccupation with or dreams of the deceased person. All of these are expected grief reactions to a loss. These tasks should be seen as guides for what the bereaved person may experience. Bereaved people do not go through these tasks in a scripted way, but rather in a variety of manners and with different timing for each person. Indications of uncomplicated grief include the painful yet forward movement toward incorporating the loss into one's life and beginning a meaningful life that involves entering into relationships and activities again.

column6: The way that a person copes and adapts to loss and his or her grief response is key to differentiating between a complicated and an uncomplicated grief process. In an uncomplicated grief reaction, there is an initial acute grief reaction, but the emotional response is time-limited, the individual utilizes existing resources and seeks outside help to cope and adapt to the loss, and there is no long-term impairment in daily functioning. In contrast, in complicated grief reactions the emotional response does not resolve, there is little or no adaptation to the changes that result from the loss, harmful behaviors can develop, and daily functioning is impaired.

Understanding the bereaved person's preexisting conditions is beneficial because those conditions can complicate the grief process. Preexisting clinical depression, for instance, can predispose someone to a complicated grief process. Many symptoms of normal grief are similar to symptoms of mental health disorders. Discernment is helped by factoring in the intensity, duration, and impact on functioning for the bereaved. Clinical depression is a good example because both grief and depression are associated with intense low mood, difficulty with the experience of pleasure, sleep disturbance, and appetite loss, which makes it difficult to distinguish between the two. Table 1, adapted from Cook and Dworkin (1992), contrasts uncomplicated grief and clinical depression. It is important to note that, although full depressive reaction may accompany normal grief response, grief usually does not include the loss of self-esteem, worthlessness, or overall sense of guilt that characterizes depression. The depressed person has consistently low mood or an absence of emotion, has little enthusiasm for previously enjoyable activities, and has little interest in others. In contrast, the grieving person has variable emotions and is likely to shift from being able to enjoy some activities to refusing activities and from wanting to be with others to preferring to be alone. Hence, having a low threshold for inquiring about depression is appropriate when treating seriously ill patients and their families. Interventions for clinical depression that occurs during the grief process may include antidepressant or anxiolytic medication and psychotherapy. Supportive therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy are two psychotherapeutic approaches that are used to treat depression during the grief process. If the physician suspects depression or other psychopathology, it may be helpful to explain to the dying or bereaved person that stress may precipitate these disorders and emphasize that the associated suffering can be treated or managed.

column3: Manage reactions to loss, including anxiety and depression
column6:
Effectively anticipating and reducing the severity of the grief reactions of patients and families begins early in the process and involves repeated assessments of anticipated and actual losses, emotional responses, and coping strategies. Gentle inquiry may provide support to the bereaved person and may help the physician understand how the survivor is coping. Cognitive, emotional, and physical reactions to grief, and the need for bereavement support, can be ongoing for months. Physicians and health care workers need to be skilled at assessing grief reactions, providing basic supportive care, and referring individuals to bereavement experts quickly if grief reactions become complicated. It is important to recognize the underlying cause of grief in order to avoid useless or misleading investigations or medication trials. Each patient's anticipated and actual losses, emotional responses, and coping strategies must be assessed frequently during the first months following a death in order to effectively anticipate and reduce the intensity of grief reactions. Gentle inquiry can help the physician to understand how the survivor is coping and to provide support. Early in the process, try to identify individuals who are at particular risk. If religion is an important component of coping, engage a chaplain or pastoral care professional to help determine and understand the religious background and framework held by each family member. Some people will make a conscious effort to manage the loss. Others will deny what is happening and avoid dealing with the loss. Some coping strategies (eg, increased smoking/alcohol/medication intake, overworking, suicidal ideation) may accelerate and even become destructive, especially in the face of seemingly insurmountable loss. Physicians and other health care professionals need to be attuned to behaviors that might indicate complicated grief, especially if such behaviors continue beyond 6 to 12 months. The survivor may not be able to speak of the deceased person without experiencing intense sadness. Themes of loss may continue to occur in every topic during a clinical interview. Minor events may unexpectedly trigger intense grief and sadness. The survivor may be unwilling to move possessions that belonged to the deceased person. The survivor may even develop symptoms that are similar to those of the deceased person. Ongoing assessment by primary care providers will help the physician distinguish uncomplicated from complicated grief reactions. Understanding the bereaved person's preexisting conditions is beneficial because those conditions can complicate the grief process. Preexisting clinical depression, for instance, can predispose someone to a complicated grief process. 
Multiple coping strategies may be needed simultaneously. The likelihood of successful coping by bereaved people appears to improve with early intervention that uses stress- reduction techniques.

The ED is usually not the optimal site for managing grief and bereavement. However, the emergency team should know enough about grief management so that the appropriate responses and resources can be made available to the family. The physician's respect for the grief process may make a difference in the ability of the dying person and the bereaved family members to move toward their life goals. For the dying person, this may involve dying in his or her chosen way, with an intact personal identity and opportunities to complete important remaining goals. For the bereaved person, this may involve appreciation of a significant relationship, acceptance of change, and development of new life patterns and relationships. Finding adaptive responses and reintegrating is a significant accomplishment. If the physician perceives that the patient or family has begun, or even achieved, this success, it is important to acknowledge and affirm it, both to reinforce the process and to foster skills that will likely be necessary each time the patient and family face a new loss.

Grief education for faculty and staff can be done using written material, interactive teaching sessions, and one-on-one intervention. Education should center on grief and the grief process, how to care for families, and how to care for staff.

Debriefing sessions can be routine or episodic. They can prove particularly valuable when a death has been especially difficult for the staff, such as the death of a young person or a death that was the result of disease or trauma. Bereavement care can be particularly useful to the ED staff if they repeatedly cared for the patient who died. Caring for patients and families during the grief and bereavement process is part of comprehensive patient care. Patients respond first to the loss of their expectations for their future, and the process continues throughout the course of the illness experience. Family members have counterpart responses and many will face bereavement. It is essential that the physician understand the processes of adaptive and maladaptive response. By acknowledging and teaching the patient and family about the process of response to loss, the physician can help them adjust to illness-related losses and to the last stages of living and bereavement. Each loss results in a need to take in the reality, creative adaptation, and reintegration. Each loss and adaptation can involve experiments with coping that fail or cause stress. They can also result in deep and meaningful relationships. These important stages often leave lasting memories for families, as well as for caregivers and professionals. Care does not end until the physician has helped the family with their grief reactions and helped to provide care for those with complicated grief. It may be best to involve a social worker, pastor, or other counseling professional if interventions are necessary to treat depression during grief and for other difficult coping mechanisms for adapting to loss

Physicians can discern and allow for the needs of the patient and family while normalizing the process. A family meeting with the nurse, social worker, or counselor to achieve the prerequisites of an optimal adaptive process may be useful, and the physician can help orchestrate this process.

column3: Encourage participatory activities/creative adaptation to losses
column6: Encourage the bereaved survivor to talk about what it is like to live without the deceased. Bereaved survivors should be encouraged to participate in rituals such as the funeral or memorial services, or to identify personal rituals and write letters to family and friends that recount the story and their feelings. After a period of time in which internal reflection has allowed the bereaved person to acknowledge the loss and become capable of recreating life with the reality of the loss, encourage him or her to participate in activities with family, friends, and community. Acknowledge that, although these activities may seem meaningless at first, they may help the bereaved person to continue engagement until meaning can be recreated.

column3: Refer for treatment of anxiety, depression or insomnia
column6: If the loss, grief reactions, and coping strategies appear to be appropriate and effective, the situation can be monitored and supportive counseling provided. If the bereaved survivors feel they are going crazy or losing their minds, they must be given adequate time to discuss their feelings. It may also help to explain that grief is painful and prolonged, but normal; that the length of time needed for the grief process will vary with each person and situation; that there is no ''right'' way to grieve and each person will have his or her own way. If counseling is insufficient, medical management of anxiety, depression, insomnia, or other common grief reactions can be helpful for short periods of time (weeks to months).

If loss, grief reactions, and coping strategies appear to be inappropriate, ineffective, or prolonged, or they have the potential to cause harm (eg, destructive behaviors or suicide), they will need to be assessed and managed aggressively. Some people will need ongoing support, psychotherapy and/or medication to manage the symptoms and reduce the intensity and protracted course of suffering as they struggle to adapt to the profound changes in their lives. Consult a psychiatrist, psychologist, or other specialist who is skilled in complicated loss, grief, and bereavement care so that therapy can be instigated rapidly to reduce the risk of harmful or destructive activities.
Immediately after a death, those who are bereaved will need time to recover from the acute stress and fatigue, and to restore their environments back to normal. As they begin to realize the significance of the loss, they will likely experience an intense grief reaction with multiple cognitive, emotional, and physical responses (see Table 1) and will require considerable ongoing support to help them deal with all the changes. Some people who are bereaved will make a conscious effort to deal with the loss, emotions, and changes that follow the death of a loved one and will seek ongoing assistance from their physicians to help them address the feelings of loss and their emotions. Others will deny what is happening and avoid dealing with any of these issues. The latter group will be at high risk for a prolonged, complicated, grieving process.

It may be appropriate for the physician to send a condolence card and attend the patient's funeral. Many physicians and members of the professional team feel it is part of their professional duty to encourage follow-up visits from family members in order to assess the severity of their grief reactions and coping strategies and to provide support.

column3: Follow through with bereaved family members after death

column6: It has been widely reported that bereaved people felt it was helpful to receive a note or letter from the doctor after a death had occurred. Such a note has two goals: to offer tribute to the deceased person as someone who was important and to be a source of comfort to the survivors. Mourners will appreciate that the physician took the time to sit and compose a personal message to them or to share a memory of the deceased person. A promptly sent letter (generally within two weeks after the death) will be far more effective than a late one. The note should be handwritten on any standard stationery. Here are some specific guidelines for writing a good condolence note: Acknowledge the loss and name the deceased person. This sets the purpose and tone of the letter. Express your sympathy. Use words of sympathy that remind the bereaved that they are not alone in their feelings of sadness and loss, such as, ''I am sure she will be missed by many.''vIf you got to know the person at all, note special qualities of the deceased person. Acknowledge those characteristics that you observed about the person who has died. These might be qualities of personality (courage, sensitivity), or attributes (funny, affable), or ways the person related to the world (religious, devoted to community welfare). Say something like, ''I will miss her sense of humor.''	If relevant, recall a memory about the deceased person. Talk about how the deceased person touched your life. Try to capture what it was about the person in the story that you admired, appreciated, or respected. You may use humor-the funny stories are often the most appreciated by those who are bereaved. Say something like, '''I particularly remember when she had all of us in the office laughing at one of her jokes about the examination gown.'' Consider reminding the bereaved people of their personal strengths.Bereavement often brings self-doubt and anxiety about one\'s own personal worth. Reminding bereaved people of the qualities that they possess will help get them through this period and reinforce their ability to cope. Qualities to mention might be patience, optimism, religious belief, resilience, and competence. Offer help, but be specific. Don't say, ''If there is anything I can do, please call.'' That puts a burden on those in grief who may be totally at a loss about what needs to be done. A definite offer of help is more appreciated. Whatever you offer, do it. Don\'t make an offer you cannot fulfill. You may want to say something such as ''I'd be happy to answer any questions you or your family might have about her illness and her care. Just make an appointment-no charge.'' End with a word or phrase of sympathy, such as, ''I'll remember your mother and the care you gave her.''

Professional members of the interdisciplinary team can also offer to assist family members (when they are ready) to deal with outstanding practical matters, secure documents to redeem insurance, find legal counsel to execute the will, meet financial obligations, close the estate, etc.

The physician can assist bereaved people who have uncomplicated grief by asking how they are coping, educating them about the grief process, and normalizing the experience. Simply offering a bereavement visit as a routine matter will help to normalize the experience. Grief counseling and support may be helpful for persons who experience uncomplicated grief. Although these individuals may not need professional intervention, they may benefit from opportunities to learn more about the grief process, to express emotions with others who have similar feelings, and to receive guidance with problem-solving as they adjust to life without the deceased person. In addition to individual, general, and specialty group counseling, hospice and palliative care programs typically provide a wide range of bereavement services, including support newsletters, memorial celebrations, and specific strategies to help cope with holidays and particular types of loss. If the patient was enrolled in hospice care, family members may be eligible for bereavement support services without charge through that hospice. Other bereaved individuals may be able to access those services for a fee
