column3: Last Hours of Living in the ED
column6: Last hours of living are typically thought of as the last 48 hours or less of a life. But,, it can be difficult to recognize when death is approaching in chronic, progressive terminal illnesses. There are multiple stressors in the ED, where the focus is on saving lives. Therefore, we (EP's) are currently unlikely to manage dying; ironically, especially in those who do not want aggressive care. But, if we can recognize the ''syndrome of imminent death'', we can manage physical and psychological symptoms in a fragile, and key time of a life for those who won't die by withdrawing life support.

column3: Recognize the patient who presents with an opportunity to die (well

column6: With skills of rapid goal setting, rapid communication, and knowledge of death trajectories we can make answer these questions: Are these tests, images, labs, procedures, or interventions really needed or recommended; and How can I reach a good disposition for this patient/family? Rapidly detecting if the patient/family are unable to accept the notion of impending death, whether they've discussed resuscitation status, whether they have the resources to care for the patient, and whether they are having trouble transitioning from aggressive care to symptom management are skills to hone. What we can do within last hours of living again boils down to goals of care, what's needed to reach those goals, and what consensus can be reached fairly quickly.

Natural death is characterized by electrolyte abnormalities, infection, and/or heart/respiratory failure; and these ED presentations may be an opportunity for the patient to die (well).  Some may live hours, days, or weeks more, and quality of life in this time is unpredictable. Base your decision to intervene on natural death on patient's goals of care. An algorithm may include progressive steps (1) immediately treating symptoms and suffering regardless of next steps, (2) rapid goals assessment, (3) negotiation of goals, and (4) reaching consensus about goals. Most need few or no tests and procedures if the goal is comfort. If the goal is to delay death maybe to achieve some other goals, fluids, antibiotics, other low-risk interventions, labs or radiographs may be appropriate. If goals are aggressive to fully reverse/improve the current state, you may order a number of things you feel are of limited effectiveness and benefit.

In last hours, all patients require 24-7 skilled care; which may warrant hospital admission if no care system is possible for that patient. That said, any setting with prepared and supported professionals, family, and/or volunteer caregivers can care for the actively dying. If a home or non-hospital death is preferred, make a referral to an out- or inpatient hospice. Depending on time of day, they may be able to accommodate a patient with hours to live. If not, the ED must accommodate as best it can. the best environment is private/intimate and allows family/friends continuous access without disturbing others. If possible, use a bay in the least trafficked area, or holding area with added chairs. anticipation problems of the last hours, and have meds, equipment, and supplies available, whether the patient is at home or in an institution.

column6: Many people fear that pain suddenly increase as the patient dies, but there is no evidence to suggest this. Continuous pain in the semiconscious or obtunded patient is difficult to assess, but may be associated with grimacing and continuous facial tension across the forehead and between the eyebrows. Do not over-diagnose constant pain when fleeting forehead tension comes and goes with movement or mental activity (dreams or hallucinations, for example). Consider the possibility of pain with physiologic indicators, e.g. transient tachycardia. Do not confuse pain with the restlessness, agitation, moaning, and groaning of terminal delirium. If unclear, trialing a higher dose of opioid may answer whether pain is driving the behaviors. Knowing opioid pharmacology is critical during last hours of life. The liver conjugates codeine, morphine, oxycodone, and hydromorphone into glucuronides. Some of their metabolites remain active as analgesics until renally cleared, particularly morphine. dying patients will all have diminishing liver/renal function, and usually become olig- or anuric. Continuing routine doses/infusions of morphine may lead to increased levels of active metabolites, toxicity, and risk of terminal delirium.

Most also reduce fluid intake, or stop drinking entirely, long before death. If still taking some fluid, but not eating, salty fluids e.g. soups, club soda, sport drinks, and red vegetable juices can balance  electrolytes and minimize nausea from hyponatremia. Decreased intake usually distresses onlookers who worry the dehydrated patient will suffer, particularly if she becomes thirsty. We can comfort them by helping them understand that most experts in the field feel that the natural dehydration  in the last hours doesn't distress the dying, and it may even stimulate endorphins. Low blood pressure or weak pulse is part of natural dying, not an indicator of dehydration. Patients unable to move don't get lightheaded. Patients with peripheral edema or ascites have excess body water and salt and are not dehydrated. Consider IV or SQ fluids using hypodermoclysis, particularly if the goal is to reverse delirium. Excess parenteral fluids can lead to fluid overload and peripheral/pulmonary edema, worsened breathlessness, cough, and orotracheobronchial secretions, particularly in hypoalbuminemia. They may also (undesirably) prolong dying.

Decreasing blood perfusion
   - As cardiac output and intravascular volume decrease you can expect these natural processes. Venous blood may pool along dependent skin surfaces. Oliguria or anuria is normal. Parenteral fluids will not reverse this circulatory shutdown.

The neurological changes of dying result from multiple, concurrent, nonreversible factors (hypoxemia; metabolic imbalance; acidosis; toxin accumulation due to liver and renal failure; adverse effects of meds; sepsis; disease-related factors; reduced cerebral perfusion). They may manifest in two patterns described as the ''two roads to death''. The ''usual road'' that 70-90% of patients follow is decreasing levels of consciousness leading to coma/death. The ''difficult road'' that 10-30% of patients follow is an agitated delirium due to CNS excitation-with or without myoclonic jerks-leading to coma/death. Focal or grand mal seizures are more likely along the difficult road, particularly with cerebral metastases. The patient is increasingly drowsy, sleeps most if not all of the time, and eventually becomes unarousable. Absence of eyelash reflex indicates a deep coma equivalent to full anesthesia.

Delirium may be the first sign to herald the difficult road. It may manifest as confusion, restlessness, and/or agitation, with or without day-night reversal. It may result from any of the standard causes of delirium listed in the DSM. Agitated terminal delirium can be very distressing to those who don't understand it. Although previous care may have been excellent, if delirium is misdiagnosed or unmanaged, family will likely remember a horrible, painful death, and fear their own death will be the same. Reassure that what they see may be very different from what the patient experiences. If delirium presents in the non-actively dying patient, you may try to reverse treatable contributors knowing this is effective in a minority of cases if the patient is close to the last hours of his or her life. Although moaning, groaning, and grimacing accompany agitation and restlessness, they are frequently misinterpreted as pain.

Changes in a dying patient's breathing pattern may be indicative of significant neurological compromise. Breaths may become very shallow and frequent with a diminishing tidal volume. Periods of apnea and/or Cheyne-Stokes pattern respirations may develop. Accessory respiratory muscle use may become prominent. A few, sometimes many, last reflex breaths may signal death. Patients and caregivers are often distressed at the mere thought of breathlessness. The ability to reassure patients and caregivers that the patient is not suffocating or the perception of breathlessness can be an extraordinary source of comfort.

column5: Loss of gag reflex, Buildup of saliva, secretions
column6: In the last hours of life, weakness and decreased neurological function frequently impair the patient's ability to swallow. The gag reflex and reflexive clearing of the oropharynx decline and secretions from the tracheobronchial tree accumulate. These conditions may become more prominent as the patient loses consciousness. Buildup of saliva and oropha- ryngeal secretions accumulate and may lead to gurgling, crackling, or rattling sounds with each breath. Some have called this the death rattle, a term frequently disconcerting to families and caregivers. For unprepared families and professional caregivers, it may sound like the patient is choking.Once the patient is unable to swallow, oral intake should be stopped. Warn families and professional caregivers of the risk of aspiration. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the earlier treatment is initiated, the better it works because larger amounts of secretions in the upper aerodigestive tract are more difficult to eliminate. However, premature use in the patient who is still alert may lead to unacceptable drying of oral and pharyngeal mucosa.

column6: Because dying in contemporary society is highly medicalized, most people have not witnessed a natural human death. For this reason, it is likely that many families and caregivers will not fully understand a patient's natural death process and this may cause them undue suffering. Averting such a situation requires that families and caregivers be given the proper information regarding how the body shuts down.  Case Based teaching point: An 89-year-old woman with adult failure to thrive and multiple episodes of sepsis presents with altered mental status. Labs reveal a serum sodium of 168mEg/dl. The patient has been unable to eat, drink, or swallow over the last month. Here is one example of how to communicate this information: ''The body is shutting down because the (disease) is taking over the body. The natural process is that the patient stops eating and drinking and that the brain begins to send and receive a different set of signals. The normal balance of chemicals in the blood becomes altered and the patient goes into a different state. We embrace all of this as normal for dying and we support each patient through this process.''

'When the person no longer has the ability to eat or drink on their own, we expect the blood to become off balance as a natural process. In order to reverse this process, she would need to be able to eat or drink on her own. When we don't expect this to reverse itself, we accept that this is the natural process of death. We could interfere with this process temporarily by introducing a feeding tube or starting and maintaining intravenous fluids. We need to weigh if we should do this or not.''

column3: When/how do I use family witnessed resuscitation?
column6: This practice has evolved sufficiently that a good experience can be achieved with family present. In the 1980s, the standard practice of uniformly excluding family members during resuscitation was questioned after research showed that family members often felt powerless, frustrated, and upset after sudden death of a loved one and that the team had not told them what they wanted to know. Families continued to request to be present in resuscitation attempts. Still, this practice is much debated among EP's. It's estimated that 20% of the estimated forty-thousand annual pediatric deaths occur in the prehospital or ED setting. Pediatric death violates our perceptions about how death should occur, so is particularly hard for families and teams, so from necessity in practice; family-centered, team-oriented approaches have been fairly widely adopted in pediatric centers.

column3: Potential risks and benefits of family-witnessed resuscitation

column6: American Heart Association guidelines from 2000 recommend family be allowed to witness CPR, which is a controversial recommendation. opponents have voiced concerns of increased litigation, family interference of resuscitation. The American Academy of Pediatrics and ACEP are jointly working on documents regarding the application of family-centered care as it pertains to the death of a child in the ED

Pediatricians are more likely to accept FWR and to make repeated attempts at FWR than their counterparts in adult medicine. In a survey of >1,200 pediatric emergency and critical care physicians, nearly all had participated in FWR and felt families should be allowed to view the process. But they also acknowledged the practice as stressful and feel house staff need training in the practice. It was also shown that inpatient-oriented pediatric specialists are far more accepting of family presence and more willing to repeat FWR. During their residencies, pediatric-trained physicians are often faced with performing resuscitations in the delivery room while parents are present so may be more comfortable with the experience.

Doyle et al. pioneered work in ED FWR at Foote Hospital in Jackson, Michigan in the mid-1980s. In this study, family were given an option of being present in critical resuscitations. Interviews afterwards of participating respondents showed that FWR was an overall positive experience.. Being present fostered allowed family to appreciate the efforts made and an opportunity to assume a more active and involved role. Of the 47 respondents, 44 (94%) said they'd choose to be present again if asked. 36 (76%) said they thought the experience facilitated their adjustment to the death, and 30 (64%) believed their presence was helpful to the dying family member. FWR may help family to understand the disease severity and that (s)he received the best interventions possible in the circumstances.

column3: Common concerns regarding practice of family-witnessed resuscitation

column6: It is natural for us to worry that FWR will undermine patient care. For what it's worth, uring the 9-year review at the Foote Hospital, family members were reported to have never interfered with a resuscitation attempt
Some argue that the physician's willingness to include the family fosters increased trust. Some authors advocate that improved communication and reassurance will lessen the likelihood of litigation.

Interestingly, a long-term follow-up of Foote Hospital's continued FWR program found that anticipated negative effects on family members failed to occur. Other studies of FWR have yielded consistently positive responses from participating families, and one randomized, controlled trial was ended early because ED staff became convinced of its benefit to families.

It can be an added stress on, especially younger, physicians. But, training and experience increases comfort level with FWR. Anecdotal reports and one study suggest that health care professionals who experience FWR first-hand often undergo a change of attitude about its benefits.

Although the literature strongly suggests the benefits of FWR, the limitations in the literature are significant enough that a definitive conclusion cannot be reached. Data collection have limited the generalizability of results, e.g. unclear demographic and gender data; small sample sizes; wide age ranges; a predominance of survey data; unclear methods of assessment; and over interpretation of study results.
Institutions should develop a policy/written protocol for FWR so that families can have reasonable expectations, since poorly prepared families may be negatively impacted.

We must negotiate artificial nutrition and hydration (ANH) frequently. ''Isn't she starving?'' or ''Isn't he dehydrated?'' are common questions in the ED and can be a primary reason for presentation. For some, the decision can be made in the next care setting, but for others (e.g., those who'll return home or go to hospice), it must be made in the ED. So we must know the evidence and the patient's goals of care. It has been suggested that even small amounts of carbohydrates may paradoxically lead to increased discomfort. this is based on studies that showed that normal healthy subjects who voluntarily fasted become anorectic, but they sensed hunger when given small amounts of carbohydrates (that quickly diminish ketone production). In chronic illness, there is a normal and gradual decrease in food and water intake that culminates in cessation of oral intake. Family and caregivers may be concerned about hunger, but there is no evidence that artificial nutrition or hydration makes a person feel less hungry. Terminally ill patients who are alert and capable of decision making usually do not complain of hunger near the end of life. If they do, it can be satisfied with very small amounts of food. Persons with advanced cancer have an increase in threshold for hunger (decreased taste) and may have decreased hypothalamic stimulation secondary to diminished gastric contractions. Dehydration may be functional to dying in advanced cancer and may allow comfort because the natural effect of dehydration is hypernatremia with accompanying altered mental status. Dry mouth and thirst are best relieved with oral swabs, lip vaseline, and ice chips. Dehydration leads to a decreased production in all bodily fluids including urine output, gastrointestinal secretions, pulmonary and pharyngeal secretions, and edema. The benefits of this decreased production are seen in the decreased need for incontinence care, decreased nausea and vomiting, and a decreased need for suctioning. Controlled trials have demonstrated that terminally ill patients who forego ANH have less discomfort than those who receive intravenous hydration.

column6: Because food and water are widely held to be forms of caring, the withholding of ANH may be misperceived as neglect by the patient, family, or other professional and volunteer caregivers. Patients and caregivers will present to the emergency department and request artificial nutrition or hydration because they fear that the patient will die without these elements. Clinicians must be able to distinguish between the terms food and artificial nutrition and hydration. ANH are medical therapies that require a physician's order, whereas food may be accessed by individuals with or without the physician's assistance. ANH must be administered via technical procedures that require medical personnel. The ingestion of food does not require such procedures or personnel. If the clinician holds personal values and beliefs regarding the ability to distinguish between food and ANH, he or she must either prioritize medical norms and accepted patient preferences or take steps to withdraw from the case to avoid violating his or her conscience. Patients with advanced cancer or dementia often present to the ED at the end of life and request that artificial fluids and nutrition be initiated.

Information is often scant in the ED, particularly during the first few minutes of an emergency response. The urgency of the situation is not conducive to meaningful or thorough conversations between the ED team and the patient, and family members are sometimes not available. The emergency clinician most likely will not immediately know the cause of the medical crisis, nor will he or she have a good grasp of how chronic illness has affected the patient. Medical records may become available, the patient's primary care physician may be reachable, and family members may arrive at the ED, but these events will most likely occur after the initial attempts to stabilize the patient. Indeed, it is most often the case that emergency clinicians use implied consent to assume that the patient wants to live and thus they initiate diagnostics and treatments without obtaining informed consent. goals of care are paramount to how much, why, and what makes sense and what doesn't for a patient's care. Patients often come to the ED in a crisis that might have been expected or anticipated given their chronic illness, yet goals of care have not been addressed so it is unclear how to respond. The ethical obligation then falls to the emergency clinician to assess, inform, and advise patients and surrogates about intervention based on disease trajectory, prognosis, and clinical effectiveness of therapies. If immediate intervention is necessary to sustain life, but clarifying discussions later reveal that such intervention is not appropriate, then withdrawal is usually appropriate.

column3: Starting then stopping: withdraw/withhold or both?
column6: The appropriateness of withholding or withdrawing such therapies once they have been initiated, however, has been poorly taught in emergency practice. Emergency practitioners sometimes find themselves interrupting a dying process with ED interventions for a patient who understands that death is imminent, expected, and perhaps even welcomed. It may sometimes become clear only after stabilization of a life threat that the emergency interventions used are unwanted by the patient or are evidently misaligned with the patient's previously stated end-of-life goals. When the support systems seem to take on an imperative of their own, this can be disconcerting to an ED team as well as distressing or even devastating to the patient and family. Concerns about starting and then stopping a treatment are real for emergency providers. One may feel that stopping ventilation or a cardiac pacemaker is akin to killing the patient. The act of omission (the failure to intervene) may feel ethically safer than the act of commission in stopping an artificial means that has sustained a patient's life. Ethicists have pointed out that withdrawal in the emergency setting can be morally superior to withholding treatments or hesitating to intervene when immediate action is called for because such interventions buy time that may allow for a fuller understanding of the patient's situation and wishes. If withdrawal is in order, the emergency clinician must have the knowledge, attitude, and skills necessary to withdraw support in a manner that imparts dignity and comfort to the patient and keeps within the constraints of professional ethics.

column6: Emergency clinicians are comfortable with initiating treatments and therapies in the emergency setting and do so on a daily basis. Among life-sustaining treatments, they tend to be more comfortable with termination of CPR because the clinical expectation of the patient's status is clear: the patient has died. After cessation of CPR, attention is usually focused on the care of the family and the clinical team. In some situations, however, the clinician may be asked to withdraw therapies from a patient who is still considered to be alive, leaving family and caretakers to witness the patient's last moments. This can involve physical distress for the patient. It can also leave lifelong traumatic memories for family members. A poorly managed therapy withdrawal can also become imprinted on a clinician's mind and may become a barrier to enhancing his or her skill set.

As a rule, the discussion of goals of care should precede the recommendation of specific treatment preferences; this will guide the clinician to discuss relevant options. The clinician usually initiates discussions of treatment preferences, but other appropriate members of the health care team can enhance the discussion and prevent subsequent conflict within the team. They may have fewer time constraints and thus be able to continue the dialogue with the patient and family. The team can also be able to provide valuable emotional support to the patient, family, and each other.

column6: To function in a sphere of global wellness, the ED team must be considerate of multiple perspectives. There must be a coordinated effort to ensure open communication and support of all team members. Prehospital providers are at particular risk for being criticized for initiating interventions that may later be deemed inappropriate and this can lead to self-reproach. This attitude is counterproductive and can impede patient care because the team then begins to focus on dysfunctions and gaps rather than optimizing and correcting situations. The anxieties of patients, families, lay caregivers, and the emergency providers often rise as a patient nears death. A discussion of withdrawing and withholding therapies that are not beneficial can be difficult if one member of the ED team wants to limit care and the remainder of the team favors employing life-extending therapies. This can lead to dysfunction at the bedside, confusion for the patient and family, and strain on working relationships. All members of the team must take responsibility to work within a framework of support, feedback, and respect.

Clinicians must familiarize themselves with the institutional policies and pertinent statutes in their practice area. Institutional policies are written in response to the general legal imperative to emergency medical care providers that they must opt for treatment that will prolong life if any doubt exists about the patient's wishes. Institutional policies of many health care facilities include considerations that are intended to protect the institution from risk. However, most states allow the patient and clinician to decide on specific treatments. Each institution has its own policies and may have developed standard forms for use with life-sustaining treatment. All states in the United States have statutes that cover issues related to withholding or withdrawing of life-sustaining treatments. Prehospital personnel are regulated by statute, and sometimes also by city ordinance. Although requirements vary, prehospital personnel are often required to provide all resuscitative and life- prolonging treatments unless a physician's order to the contrary is in place.

      1. e.g.:''We have a 20-year-old male who has suffered a blunt traumatic cardiac arrest, with no return of spontaneous circulation.''
   2. Recap events 
      1. e.g.: ''I want to review what we have done. The resuscitation has been in progress for 65 minutes from prehospital to now with successful airway control, effective chest compressions, bilateral chest needle decompression, fluid resuscitation with 4 liters of crystalloid and pericardiocentecis without fluid from the pericardium.''
   3. Allow for suggestions
      1. ''Does anyone in the room have any other suggestion for what we can do that may be beneficial for this patient?'' (The clinician should instruct the continuation of CPR and allow time for any member of the team to comment and acknowledge suggestions.)
   4. Explicit statement of team comfort 
      1. Example: ''Is everyone comfortable with stopping resuscitation?''
   5. Pronounce death 
      1. Example: ''With consensus, the patient is pronounced dead at 20:33 hours.'' Practically speaking, termination of CPR leads to death disclosure. If the family is not at the bedside in the ED, the death disclosure comes in two parts: (1) disclosure of death to the medical team and (2) disclosure of death to the family.
   6. Thank the team/acknowledge difficulty 
      1. Example: ''Thank you team, everyone. This is never easy. I appreciate your hard work on this difficult case. Please take a minute to reflect in your own way.''

column5: ''We have discussed your current illness , have you given any thought to how you would like to be cared for at the time of death? Sometimes when people die, or are near death, especially from a sudden illness, life support measures are used to try and ''bring them back''; alternatively, we can focus on keeping you comfortable. How do you feel about this? "

column3: Sustained requests for CPR that's not medically appropriate/indicated
column5:
1.  "What do you know about CPR?"
   2.   "This decision seems very hard for you. I want tot give you the best medical care possible; can you tell me more about your decisions?"
   3. "What do you expect will happen?"
   4. ''What do you think would be done differently, after the resuscitation that wasn't being done before?"
   5. ''Based on what you see on television, I know that it seems that most patients who get CPR live, but this is not the case. We only start CPR at the moment of death and it is an attempt to reverse the moment of death. The vast majority of patients who get CPR will not have death reversed. I would only recommend that for you if I thought you were in the group of patients who survive to go home. Unfortunately, because of your severe heart failure, I would not recommend it.''
   6.  If you will honor the request for CPR:
      1. ''I understand your desire for CPR, but I will need some direction if you survive, since you will almost certainly be on a breathing machine in an ICU. It is very likely you will not be able to make decisions for yourself. Who do you want to make decisions for you?''
      2.  '' Please give me some sense of how long we should continue life support if you are not able to make decisions and there's no improvement in your condition.''
   7. If participating in CPR violates your professional judgment: 
      1. ''I understand your desire for CPR, but in my medical judgement performing CPR would only increase your suffering and NOT prevent your dying. Although I would like to continue caring for you, I am unwilling to participate in the CPR; it may be appropriate for you to find another physician to provide your care."

column6: Do not delay withdrawal as a way of avoiding the issue. The withdrawal of ventilator support is one of the most challenging situations for patients, families, and members of the health care team. With the realities of ED overcrowding and ''boarding,'' patients often receive intensive care in the ED. Long waits for intensive care unit beds often require that the ED team be involved in decisions such as ventilator withdrawal. Or a patient may have been placed on a ventilator in the prehospital setting or in the ED when little information was known, with the subsequent discovery of a medical directive that excludes the use of ventilation and resuscitation. Or appropriate surrogates may insist that the patient would not want the aggressive measures that are being undertaken and request cessation of efforts. Emergency clinicians should respect the wishes of the patient and the surrogates as much as possible. Due diligence in establishing that withdrawal is, indeed, appropriate is a necessity, but once done the clinician should not delay withdrawal as a way of avoiding the issue (eg, do not needlessly wait until transfer to the ICU). In discussing whether to institute or withdraw artificial ventilation, the clinician should follow the general outline for discussing life-sustaining treatments and employ a team approach, including the nurse, social worker, chaplain, and emergency medical services personnel as appropriate.

After it has been established that the patient or surrogate desires withdrawal, the stage must be properly set despite the constraints of the ED. If possible, the patient and family should have a private room and preparation should be made to ensure that they will not have to be moved if another critical patient arrives.The family should be involved in the decision to withdraw the ventilator. They should understand the procedure and be reassured about their roles. Because of the degree of uncertainty involved, it is also important for the clinician to prepare the family for the range of outcomes that might occur. The ED team should never make assumptions about what the family understands. The clinician should describe the procedure in clear, simple terms and answer any questions

If ventilator withdrawal seems appropriate to everyone involved, two methods of withdrawal should be considered: (1) immediate extubation and (2) terminal weaning. The choice of which method to use will be influenced by the patient's comfort, the family's perceptions, and the clinician's assessment. It is critical that the patient be comfortable both throughout the withdrawal procedure and afterward. The most important and prevalent symptoms of ventilator withdrawal are breathlessness and anxiety.

If the patient is conscious, it must be determined whether he or she would like to remain conscious as the ventilator is withdrawn. This will determine the endpoints for initial medication and guide the use of additional medication during the procedure. If the patient wishes to remain awake, opioids and benzodiazepines should be initiated at low doses. Plans should be in place to intervene if severe breathlessness or discomfort ensues after extubation. The clinician should also discuss how and when it may become necessary to titrate to an endpoint of sedation

The family should be made aware of what is likely to happen. The family and caregivers should be assured that the patient's comfort is of primary concern. The ED team should explain that breathlessness and discomfort may occur, but medications will be available to manage these symptoms.The family should discuss ahead of time the possibility that occasionally it is necessary to induce sleep in the patient to manage symptoms. The family should understand how terminal sedation is distinct from hastening death (see also ''Terminal sedation and the doctrine of double effect'' below). They should be aware that involuntary moving or gasping need not reflect suffering if the patient is properly sedated or in a coma.In spite of efforts to avoid distress, perfection is rare. For instance, efforts can be made to avoid the sound of the ''death rattle'' (see also below ''Secretion management / death rattle'') but accumulation of fluid deep in the trachea may occur which can be distressing to the family. The family should be reassured that this is a natural process and does not indicate that the patient is in distress.
The family should be encouraged to show love and support by talking to or touching the patient, stroking the patient's forehead, or holding the patient's hand.

The clinician should explain that there is always some uncertainty about what will happen after the ventilator is withdrawn. Some patients die within several minutes, but others may live for longer periods. The family should be cautioned that although death is expected, it is not certain. Data show that approximately 10% of patients survive ventilator withdrawal and are discharged from the hospital.

This step establishes a concrete expectation by the family of the patient's death. It is also part of providing for important relevant orders and documentation and it prevents inappropriate calls for resuscitation.
(Employ a team approach: nurse, social worker, chaplain, emergency medical services). Respect wishes of the patient/surrogate as much as possible.

column3: Meet in advance to discuss plan for care
column6: The ED team (physician, primary nurse, charge nurse, and, ideally, also the technicians, respiratory therapist, pharmacist, chaplain, and social worker) should meet in advance to discuss the plan of care. If at all possible, the withdrawal procedure should not be scheduled during a shift change

The ED team should anticipate potential discomfort and institute appropriate medical and nonmedical measures in advance in order to prevent occurrence of these symptoms. Medication should be immediately available at the bedside so that it can be rapidly titrated to the level appropriate to ensure the patient's comfort. The ED team should ensure that the patient is comfortable before withdrawing the ventilator and also verbally reassure the patient and the family that he or she will be kept comfortable throughout the process and afterward.

column3: Terminal sedation and the doctrine of double effect
column6: Occasionally, refractory symptoms lead the patient, family, and professional team to conclude that the only option for securing comfort for the patient is sedation. If it is not possible to lighten the sedation without a return to unbearable suffering, this sedation can be terminal. Terminal sedation has been somewhat controversial. Terminal sedation should not be conducted without involvement of senior experts

The emergency clinician should have a plan for the mode of ventilator withdrawal and should reach clinical consensus with the nurses, respiratory therapist, and any other members of the team who will be at the bedside and interact with the family. The ED team must be coordinated and work in concert so that families and patients do not become uncomfortable with any hesitancy or bedside confusion regarding the plan.

In immediate extubation, the endotracheal tube is removed after appropriate premedication and suctioning. Humidified air or oxygen is given to prevent drying of the airway. This is the preferred approach to relieve discomfort if the patient is conscious, the secretions volume is low, and the airway is unlikely to be compromised after extubation. Although most authorities regard immediate extubation as ethically sound practice, some may experience it as intentionally ending the patient's life. Provided the intent is to allow natural death from the terminal condition, and provided guidelines endorsed by a medical professional body are carefully followed, this is not killing. Nonetheless, emotional experience of what it feels like is important and procedures that feel wrong should be avoided whenever possible, replacing them with an approach that feels appropriate.

In what some have called terminal weaning, the ventilator rate, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and oxygen levels are decreased while the endotracheal tube is left in place. Terminal weaning may be carried out over a period of 30 to 60 minutes or longer. Narcosis from accumulating carbon dioxide may stimulate endorphin release that further sedates the patient. Often, the endotracheal tube can be left in place with a Briggs T-piece in place of the ventilator. Alternatively, the patient may be extubated.
The clinician or assisting nurse should have a syringe of a sedating medication such as midazolam, lorazepam, or diazepam ready to use in case distressing tachypnea or other symptoms occur.

Opioids (such as morphine) are the most effective medication for relieving the sense of breathlessness. They work through both central and peripheral mechanisms of action. The principle of intended versus unintended consequences governs the use of opioids in this setting Concerns about unintended secondary effects, such as shortened life, are exaggerated, particularly if established dosing guidelines are followed. The dose should be titrated with the intent of achieving comfort. Doses that are increased beyond the level needed to achieve comfort or sedation can hasten death and constitute euthanasia. Oxygen is helpful to correct hypoxemia, but may not relieve breathlessness (see Module 10: Common Symptoms). An opioid-nai?ve patient should be given a bolus dose of 2 to 10 mg of morphine IV to prevent breathlessness.

Benzodiazepines such as midazolam and lorazepam are the most effective anxiolytic drugs in this setting and are usually used in combination with opioids for severe breathlessness. Opioids have transient and unreliable anxiolytic effects in opioid-nai?ve patients and should not be used for this purpose. When persistent dyspnea is expected, initial opioid doses should be followed with a continuous morphine infusion at 50% of bolus dose/h to maintain the desired effect. An infusion at 1 mg/h can be started after a bolus of midazolam. Both medications should be titrated to minimize anxiety and achieve the desired state of comfort and sedation. Lorazepam may be used as an alternative. Higher doses will be required if these medications have been routinely used and pharmacologic tolerance develops. There is no need to increase the doses once comfort and the desired level of sedation have been achieved. Aggressive symptom control is needed if distress ensues once the ventilator has been withdrawn. The clinician may wish to consider using morphine, 5 to 10 mg IV push q 10 min, and/or midazolam, 2 to 4 mg IV push q 10 min, until distress is relieved. Both infusion rates should be adjusted to maintain relief. The doses recommended here are intended for patients who have not previously taken anxiolytic medications or opioids.

Appropriate plans to prevent the gurgling sound of secretions in the airway (known as the death rattle) should be made in advance. This may include the use of an anticholinergic agent such as IV glycopyrolate, atropine, or scopolamine. The ED team and the family should be educated about the physiological aspects of death rattle and its implications, including the fact that it does not signify respiratory distress or choking
Once initial symptom control has been established, the FiO2 on the ventilator should be set to 21% and the patient should be observed for signs of respiratory distress.

Opioids and benzodiazepines should be adjusted to relieve distress before proceeding further. If a patient is likely to develop CO2 narcosis with a decrease in ventilator settings, he or she may be less in need of sedating medications. If the patient appears comfortable, preparation for removal of the endotracheal tube should begin.

column3: Deflate ET tube cuff, turn off ventilator, and get out of way
Remove tube beneath a clean towel
column6: The clinician may wish to try a few moments of ''no assist'' before the endotracheal tube is removed. When ready to proceed, the endotracheal (ET) tube cuff should be deflated. If possible, an ED team member should be available to silence the ventilator, turn it off, and move it out of the way. Once the cuff is deflated, the ET tube should be removed underneath of a clean towel to collect most of the secretions and keep the ET tube covered. It may be necessary to suction excessive oropharyngeal secretions.

column6:
1. Turn off alarms 
   1. The clinician should personally ensure that all monitors and alarms in the room are turned off and assign staff to override alarms that cannot be turned off if they are triggered. 
2. Remove all restraints
3. Ensure room for family/caregivers 
   1. Sufficient space around the bedside should be made available to family and caregivers. Nasogastric tubes and any other needless or disfiguring or unnecessary devices that may be crowding the bedside should be removed before the family enters the room. If the patient is an infant or young child, the parent should be allowed to hold the child. 
4. Allow family to hold patient, if child
5. Maintain IV access for palliative medicines
6. after-death care 
   1. Then pressors should then be turned off and intravenous access should be maintained for administration of palliative medications.
7. Encourage family to take the time they need with the patient 
   1. At this point, the family should be allowed to approach their loved one whose face is now no longer encumbered by medical devices. A nurse should be stationed at the opposite side of the bed with a washcloth and oral suction catheter. Tissues should be available for extra secretions, and for tears. The family should be encouraged to hold the patient's hand and provide assurances to their loved one. Administration of symptom-management medications should continue for as long as they may be needed.
8. Inform of next steps for the deceased 
   1. Offer acute grief support
   2. Offer follow up bereavement support, as appropriate 
      1. When they are ready to leave, the family should be informed about the next steps of care for patients who have died in the ED. Follow-up bereavement support should be offered in accordance with institutional policies.

1. Appropriate orders for symptom relief
   2. DNR orders consistent with hospital policy
column6: The emergency clinician should be prepared to write (1) appropriate orders for symptom relief and (2) a do-not-resuscitate order that is consistent with policies and procedures of the hospital. There should be a clear discussion and consensus with the patient and family about not restarting the ventilator once it is removed and about the DNR status (see also Module 4: Advance Directives). If this consensus cannot be achieved, ventilator withdrawal should be postponed. The actual withdrawal of intervention should be conducted carefully because it will probably remain in the memories of all present for a long time. Protocols for withdrawal are described below
